Award.AwardTitle: Plasmon Resonances and Metal Insulator Transitions in Highly Correlated Thin Film Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
This award supports a project with a goal of understanding the transition between metallic and insulating phases in materials where the electrons are strongly correlated with each other. The research will explore the metallic phase of vanadium dioxide thin films after the material has undergone a light-induced insulator-to-metal transition. The project will elucidate the unusual electro-optical properties of vanadium dioxide. The understanding developed as a result of the experiments may open new opportunities to actively control and tailor the properties of novel optical devices (e.g. switches) and sensors. The project will enable strong cross-fertilization and synergy between distinct disciplines such as optics, condensed matter and materials science. In addition, the proposed program will offer a rich spectrum of interdisciplinary educational opportunities for students. Components of the research project will be used to enrich the teaching curriculum as well as in the development of exciting outreach activities for the broader community.

****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
This award supports research focusing on the metal-insulator phase transition in vanadium dioxide (VO2) thin films and multi-layered structures. The goal is to obtain a better understanding of the nature of this transition [electronic (Mott) vs structural (Peierls)] by studying the nucleation and evolution of the metallic phase in the films after undergoing a light-induced insulator-to-metal transition. Modifications to the excitation of surface plasmon polaritons in either metallic VO2 or the adjacent conducting material (gold, silver, rutheniun dioxide, etc.) during the relaxation process will be investigated. The improved understanding of this phase transition and associated changes in the VO2 electro-optical properties will then be used to in an attempt to dynamically control surface plasmon or polariton propagation in multilayered structures. The ability to have such control may lead to novel applications. The project will involve a rich spectrum of interdisciplinary educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. In addition demonstrations will be developed for use in the classroom and as outreach activities to the broader community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project was to study the unique properties of vanadium dioxide thin films. This material is able to change from an electrical insulator to a conductor when its temperature is increased above its critical temperature (~68C) or when it is illuminated by very strong laser pulses. One of the main focus of our research was to improve  our undertanding on how the microstructure properties of the film affects the parameters under which such transition occurs, thus offering ways to tailor properties for various applications.

In particular, we compared the electrical and optical properties of several vanadium dioxide films, grown under nominally identical conditions on different substrate material (quartz, sapphire and rutile). By carefully characterizing such films, we found that microstructural differences in the vaadium dioxide films due to the substrates, can lead to significant modification of the temperature required to transition the film from the insulating to the conducting phase. 

Using various experimental arrangements we also confirmed that during the phase transition the film transitions in inhomogeneous fashion, through  nucleation of metallic "puddles" withing the insulating phase, that  continue to coarsen until the full sample becomes a conductor. We demonstrated that such process can be directly detected by measuring changes in the optical properties of the film undergoaing the  transition using electromagnetic radiation of different wavelegths. Since the effect of the conducting puddles becomes evident only when their size approaches the light wavelegth, it is possible to directly monitor the puddle size using far optical fields.

We also investigated the temporal transition of  the vanadium dioxide film into its conducting state after interaction with strong optical pulses. We saw that the initial transition happens very quicly (withing a fraction of a billionth of a billionth of a second), but then, depending on the temperature of the sample and the power of the laser, can continue changing, increasing its metallicity. We correlated such behavior with two possible reasons: one due to access to free electrons, produced by the absoprtion of the laser pulse, and the other is due to induced vibrations of the crystal lattice. We observed that the characteristics of such behavior are strongly influenced by the microstructure of the vanadium dioxide films, controlled by the substrate -material, crystallinity and orientation- choice. Similarly, we observed that the substrate choice can produce a dramatic difference on how long it takes for the film to return in its insulating state, resulting in more than 100-time increase in the characteristic relaxation time comparing films grown on sapphire and rutile substrates.

Finally, we investigated the possibility to use vanadium dioxide to excite surgace plasmons. These are evanescence electromagnetic waves existing at a conductor/insulator interface, and propagating only along the surface under appropriate excitation conditions. Since such surface plasmon excitations are extremely sensitive to the environment as well as to the surface properties, they are currently revolutionizing many apprications in sensing, imaging and quantum applications. We were able to demonstrate that such suface plasoms can be excited in the conducting phase in vanadium dioxide films. Moreover, it turns out that vanadium dioxide is a very promising material for plasmonic applications in the infrared region, since it has lower losses compare to traditional metals in this spectral range.
